demos.bags

Class RandomAccessBag<Item>

  • java.lang.Object
    • demos.bags.RandomAccessBag<Item>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Bag<Item>, java.lang.Iterable<Item>

    public class RandomAccessBag<Item>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Bag<Item>
    A RandomAccessBag is a Bag which, when shake()d, essentially just shakes the index sequence into the old linear collection of Items. The goal is to prove that, after shaking, and for a relatively large number of Items held, looping through the items using the Iterator returned by iterator() will lead to many cache misses and will thus be slow.
    See Also:
    StaticallyPerturbedBag, DynamicallyShuffledBag

      • shake

        public void shake()

        "Shakes" the bag, randomly perturbing the order of its elements.

        The shaking routine for a RandomAccessBag will generate the list of indices into the existing array. randomly permute that index list, and then use the permuted indices to access the existing list. The hope is that this will lead to lots of cache misses. It is also burdened by the generation of original index list as well as the permutation of its elements. Check the Java 8 branch for various optimizations for array handling.

        Specified by:
        shake in interface Bag<Item>
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        DynamicallyShuffledBag.shake()
